moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Qe7: This is known as the Gunderam defense.
moves.3. d4: Nc3 is usually a pretty popular response instead, since Nd5 is protected by Pe4 and can be followed by NxPc7+ which forks the king and rook.  Black has decent defenses against that, though.
moves.3... a5: Black usually plays d6 or Nc6 or Nf6.  Pa5 is not really recommended.
moves.4. dxe5 d6 5. exd6 cxd6: I would lean towards QxPd6 instead, to prevent isolating that d pawn.
moves.6. Bb5+ Bd7 7. Na3 Qxe4+ 8. Be3 f6 9. Bd: Oof.  Black should have played Na6, to protect against Nc7+.  Better yet, black should probably not have moved Pd5 earlier (10).
moves.14. Bxa6 Qxa6: Good.  This prevents doubling pawns (PxNa6) while attacking Na8.
moves.15. Nc7 Qa7: I like Qb6 better, which attacks Pb2.  But this sets up BxPf2+, which eliminates white's ability to castle.
moves.16. O-O: Unless white beats black to it.
moves.16... g5 17. Bg3 h5: Here white is strongly encouraged to play QxPd5.
moves.18. h4: Moving the castle pawns is generally not a great idea.
moves.18... Ne7: This was a good move on black's part.
moves.19. hxg5 fxg5 20. Nxg5 Kc8: Black needed to either move the king to prevent Nf7+ rook fork on the other side.  Rf8 would have been another option, putting pressure on white's f pawn.
moves.21. Be5 Rg8: Black withdraws support of Ph5.  Of course the rook had to be moved, but Rf8 might have been better.
moves.22. Qxh5 Bd4: Solid move--this attacks Pb2.  If white trades he will need to move Nc7 or lose Pb2 to the black queen.
moves.25... Re8: That was an awkward mistake.  White will certainly play NxRe8.  BxN will be answered with Ne6+ driving the king away from the bishop so QxBe8.
moves.26. Rxe7: Completely not the way I would have played this.
moves.26... Rxe7 27. Qf8+ Be8 28. Rd1: I think I would have gone for Nce6+ instead, to protect the knight.
moves.28... d4: While protecting that pawn is nice, RxNc7 is probably better.  RxPd5+, Rd7.
